hints.content: Start by understanding the operations defined in the problem. You will be appending elements to two separate arrays, arr1 and arr2, based on the conditions given. Make sure to track which operation corresponds to which index in the nums array.
Remember that the first two operations are fixed: the first element goes to arr1 and the second to arr2. This means you can initialize arr1 and arr2 with the first two elements of nums.
For subsequent operations (from the third element onward), you need to compare the last elements of arr1 and arr2. This comparison will dictate which array receives the next element from nums.
When comparing the last elements of arr1 and arr2, think about how to access the last element. In Python, for example, you can use negative indexing: arr1[-1] gives you the last element of arr1.

Consider edge cases where the lengths of arr1 and arr2 might differ. However, since you are always appending one element to each array in the first two operations, they will always start with one element each.
As you append elements to arr1 or arr2, make sure to maintain the order of elements as they appear in nums. This means you should not rearrange nums; just select elements based on the conditions.
After processing all elements, you will need to concatenate arr1 and arr2 to form the final result. In many programming languages, this can be done using a simple concatenation operation.
Pay attention to the constraints: the length of nums is between 3 and 50, and all elements are distinct. This means you won't have to handle duplicates, simplifying your logic.

Think about how you will implement the loop for processing the elements of nums after the first two. You can use a for loop that starts at index 2 (the third element) and goes to the end of the nums array.
Your final implementation should return the concatenated result of arr1 and arr2. Ensure that your return statement correctly formats the output as specified in the problem.

questionNotes: All elements in nums are distinct.
1-indexed array: remember that the first operation corresponds to nums[1].
Return format: concatenate arr1 and arr2 into a single array.
